thread.title: Plan your week’s theatre: top tickets
thread.title_full: Plan your week’s theatre: top tickets

author: Lyn Gardner
title: Plan your week’s theatre: top tickets
text:
Monday 30 January 2017 07.00   Monday 30 January 2017 07.02   Close Monday 
Alexander Zeldin’s compassionate play about homelessness, Love , continues at Birmingham Rep . Compagnie Mossoux-Bonté’s Whispers is at the Traverse in Edinburgh as part of the excellent Manipulate festival of visual theatre, which this week also includes Company of Wolves’ The End of Things, Jordan and Skinner’s Sanitise about our obsession with dirt, and Pickled Image’s clowning show, Coulrophobia. Tuesday 
The Hunting Lodge, Ignace Cornelissen’s love story gone wrong for teenagers, is directed by Purni Morell at the Unicorn in London. Lizzie Nunnery ’s Narvik , a play with songs set during the second world war, goes on tour from Home in Manchester . Cheek by Jowl’s The Winter’s Tale stops off at Cambridge Arts . The Yard’s annual festival of new performance, Now 17 , kicks off today and continues until early March. London’s New Diorama hosts a showcase of work from Hull, 2017’s UK city of culture, featuring emerging theatre companies Silent Uproar, Bellow, Pub Corner Poets and Middle Child. The wonderfully poetic but brutal Pink Mist pitches up at Aberystwyth Arts Centre tonight and tomorrow. Also check out Hidden at Manchester’s new venue the Horsfall , where Annette Mees and Tom Bowtell draw on Philip K Dick and Isaac Asimov in an immersive show with young carers exploring how we might care for people in the future. Watch the trailer for Narvik on YouTube Wednesday 
Crew for Calais are at the Vault festival in London over the next three weeks with three different performances, all raising funds to bring aid to refugees. Hull Truck hosts the very clever and often witty Showstopper! The Improvised Musical for just one night. Inky Cloak’s We Raise Our Hands in Sanctuary at the Albany looks at the erasure through gentrification of queer spaces. At Oval House in London, David Foster Wallace’s Mister Squishy provides the inspiration for Toot’s Focus Group, a piece looking at the loneliness of modern existence. Kirsten Childs’ The Bubbly Black Girl Sheds Her Chameleon Skin, directed by Josette Bushell-Mingo, opens at Theatre Royal Stratford East and charts a changing political landscape for women from the 1960s to the 90s. School Play at Southwark Playhouse considers the pressures of the primary school. The latest piece from 20 Stories High’s latest is called I Told My Mum I Was Going on an RE Trip and is about abortion; it’s at Contact in Manchester until Saturday. Tortoise in a Nutshell’s investigation into mental health, Fisk, is at Eden Court in Inverness today only. Fisk, sailing into Inverness on Wednesday. Photograph: Jens Peter Engedal Thursday 
Eve Klein and Sons’ work Cloth (about a woman’s deepest desires) and La Causeuse (which explores a doomed romance), form a double bill in Manipulate’s On the Road at the Tobacco Factory in Bristol . Antic Disposition set off from Southwark Cathedral on a tour of UK cathedrals with Henry V. Titus Halder’s Run the Beast Down at the Finborough , Chelsea, is a tale of delusion featuring an electronic score. Spillikin at the Drum in Plymouth is an unusual love story featuring a robot. Meet Fred, playing at Salisbury Playhouse , is Blind Summit and Hijinx’s satire about a puppet adrift in the benefits system. Friday and the weekend 
Tonight Sandi Toksvig ’s new comedy, Silver Lining, set in a retirement home, and starring Sheila Reid, opens at the Rose in Kingston . Also tonight you can get a first glimpse of Dr Frankenstein, Selma Dimitrijevic’s reworking of Mary Shelley’s book, which is at Northern Stage in Newcastle. Kathryn Hunter stars in Graeae’s production of The House of Bernarda Alba at the Royal Exchange in Manchester . On Saturday, George Bernard Shaw’s Pygmalion is reimagined by Sam Pritchard as a fable about class mobility in Britain today. It’s at the West Yorkshire Playhouse in Leeds before touring widely. On Sunday in London, check out New Diorama’s Taking Flight , a showcase of new plays by Asian writers.
